clinical_study.brief_title: Neuropsychoanalytic Treatment of Failed Back Surgery Syndrome-Opioid Dependence
clinical_study.official_title: Neuropsychoanalytic Treatment of Failed Back Surgery Syndrome-Opioid Dependence

lead_sponsor.agency: State University of New York - Upstate Medical University

clinical_study.source: State University of New York - Upstate Medical University

brief_summary.textblock: Opioid Dependent Patients who have failed back surgery syndrome are detoxified and treated with a neuropsychoanalytic paradigm.

detailed_description.textblock: Patients were detoxified from opioid analgesics and treated with NSAIDs and other non-opioid analgesics, received neuropsychoanalytic therapy and low dose naltrexone. Patients kept a daily diary of: 0 - 10 pain, 0 - 10 function, hours worked, amount of alcohol drunk, illicit and licit drug use, number of health care provider appointments attended, number of self-help groups meetings attended across each of the six months of study. Six month outcomes of this approach with primary outcomes being sobriety, pain scores and function scores.

primary_outcome.description: Detoxified patients followed for whether their pain improved.

arm_group.description: Outpatient detoxification, intensive neuropsychoanalytic therapy, low dose naltrexone, monthly evaluations for six months - case series approach.

study_pop.textblock: Adults with failed back surgery syndrome and opioid use disorder 18 years of age and older

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
1. Have failed back surgery syndrome.
2. Have evidence of Opioid Dependence by meeting DSM-IV criteria and by Drug Abuse Screening Test > 4. (In case of a difference in these two measures, clinical staff will talk with the patient to adjudicate the difference.)
3. Over 18
4. Be able to understand spoken and written English
5. Reside within 30 miles of the site of treatment for ease of followup
6. Have health insurance or other ability to pay for treatment
Exclusion Criteria:
1. Homeless
2. Unable to give consent (e.g. neurological disorders, dementia, psychosis)
3. Co-occurring incapacitating psychiatric disorder such as schizophrenia
4. Pregnant
5. Financial incentive to stay ill, such as a pending disability claim
6. Member of a vulnerable population, including prisoners
